# Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act



The **Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act** (**PURPA**, Pub. [S2] L.Tooltip Public Law (United States) 95–617, 92 Stat. [S3] 3117, enacted November 9, 1978) is a United States Act passed as part of the National Energy Act. [S4] It was meant to promote energy conservation (reduce demand) and promote greater use of domestic energy and renewable energy (increase supply). [S5] The law was created in response to the 1973 energy crisis, and one year in advance of a second energy crisis. [S6] Upon entering the White House, President Jimmy Carter made energy policy a top priority. [S7] The law started the energy industry on the road to restructuring. [S8] ## Law

PURPA was originally passed with the intention of conserving electric energy, increasing efficiency in facilities and resources used by utility companies, making retail rates for electric consumers more fair, speeding up the creation of hydroelectric energy production at small dams, and conserving natural gas. [S9] The main vehicle that the PURPA law used to try and accomplish these goals was by creating a new class of electric generating facilities called “qualifying facilities” (QFs). [S10] PURPA gave QFs special rate and regulatory treatment. [S11] The Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 (PURPA) encouraged:

* creating a market for power from non-utility power producers
* increased efficiency by making use of cogeneration
* ending promotional rate structures
* encouraging the development of hydroelectric power
* the conservation of electric energy and natural gas

## Non-utility power producers

Energy companies were classified as natural monopolies, and for this reason, most were established with vertically integrated structures (that is, they undertook all the functions of generating, transmitting, and distributing electricity to the customer). [S12] Utilities became protected as regulated monopolies because it was thought that a company could produce power more efficiently and economically as one company than as several. [S13] PURPA started the industry on the road to restructuring and is one of the first laws that began the deregulation of energy companies. [S14] The provision which enabled non-utility generators ("NUGs") to produce power for use by customers attached to a utility's grid broke the previous monopoly in the generation function. [S15] ## Ending promotional rate structure

Utilities offered customers a "rate structure" that decreased the cost per kWh price of electricity with increasing usage, with subsequent increments costing less per unit. [S16] PURPA eliminated promotional rate structures except when they could be justified by the cost structure of utility companies. [S17] ## Cogeneration

One provision of PURPA is the requirement for increased use of energy cogeneration. [S18] The law forced electric utilities to buy power from other more efficient producers, such as cogeneration plants, if that cost was less than the utility's own "avoided cost" rate to the consumer; the avoided cost rate was the additional costs that the electric utility would incur if it generated the required power itself, or if available, could purchase its demand requirements from another source. [S19] At the time generally, where demand was growing, this "avoided cost" was considered to be the construction and fossil fuel costs incurred in the operation of another thermal power plant.

[S5] When oil prices went down, utilities had to honor the rates of those contracts, leading to high power prices. In September 2019, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) announced its intention to update certain provisions of the PURPA law, in a process known as a “notice of proposed rulemaking” (NOPR). [S4] One of the original intentions of PURPA was to try to break the U.S.'s dependence on fossil fuels during the 1970s energy crisis. [S5] To accomplish that, PURPA encouraged creation of small power production facilities called “qualifying facilities” (QFs). [S6] QFs produce power from sources other than fossil fuels, or they make power using a combination of fossil fuels with renewable energy sources. [S7] In the NOPR, FERC asserted that today the country has a high supply of “relatively inexpensive” natural gas due to technological advances and the discovery of new gas reserves. [S8] Therefore, FERC wrote, there is no longer the same need now as there was in 1978 to address natural gas shortages. [S9] When PURPA was originally passed in the late 1970s, many utility companies were “vertically integrated” and did not want to buy power from third-party independent generators. [S10] However, today the system and market is much different: the market has open-access transmission and there is a wholesale market that allows utilities to buy power from independent generators at competitive market prices. [S11] Today, most energy production based on renewable resources does not require reliance on PURPA. [S12] In September 2019, during a FERC hearing, its Chairman Neil Chatterjee voiced his support for making changes to PURPA in light of “tremendous technological advances in renewables” since passage of PURPA in 1978. [S13] One idea for updating PURPA is to give more flexibility to individual states to use more competitive prices when setting QF rates. [S14] Investor-owned utility companies, represented by their national association the Edison Electric Institute (EEI), supported FERC’s proposed updates to PURPA. [S15] According to the head of the Edison Electric Institute, PURPA requires utilities to buy energy from QFs at prices that are often higher than market prices, resulting in “billions of dollars in additional consumer costs". [S16] EEI also stated it more bluntly: PURPA requires its member utilities to buy power it often doesn’t even need at mandatory above-market prices. [S17] The National Rural Electric Cooperative Association and the American Public Power Association also supported FERC's proposed changes. [S18] A group of opponents, which included eight attorneys general, the FTC, and electric power supply companies, wrote FERC to express their opposition. [S19] They laid out their concerns that FERC would be overstepping its authority in making these changes, something legal and renewables groups had argued as well. [S20] The states also raised concerns that the rules could harm renewables deployment in their states and others according to the electric industry news site UTILITY DIVE.

### 2019 FERC notice of proposed rulemaking

In September 2019, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) announced its intention to update certain provisions of the PURPA law, in a process known as a “notice of proposed rulemaking” (NOPR). [S4] One of the original intentions of PURPA was to try to break the U.S.'s dependence on fossil fuels during the 1970s energy crisis. [S5] To accomplish that, PURPA encouraged creation of small power production facilities called “qualifying facilities” (QFs). [S6] QFs produce power from sources other than fossil fuels, or they make power using a combination of fossil fuels with renewable energy sources. [S7] In the NOPR, FERC asserted that today the country has a high supply of “relatively inexpensive” natural gas due to technological advances and the discovery of new gas reserves. [S8] Therefore, FERC wrote, there is no longer the same need now as there was in 1978 to address natural gas shortages. [S9] When PURPA was originally passed in the late 1970s, many utility companies were “vertically integrated” and did not want to buy power from third-party independent generators. [S10] However, today the system and market is much different: the market has open-access transmission and there is a wholesale market that allows utilities to buy power from independent generators at competitive market prices. [S11] Today, most energy production based on renewable resources does not require reliance on PURPA. [S12] In September 2019, during a FERC hearing, its Chairman Neil Chatterjee voiced his support for making changes to PURPA in light of “tremendous technological advances in renewables” since passage of PURPA in 1978. [S13] One idea for updating PURPA is to give more flexibility to individual states to use more competitive prices when setting QF rates. [S14] Investor-owned utility companies, represented by their national association the Edison Electric Institute (EEI), supported FERC’s proposed updates to PURPA. [S15] According to the head of the Edison Electric Institute, PURPA requires utilities to buy energy from QFs at prices that are often higher than market prices, resulting in “billions of dollars in additional consumer costs". [S16] EEI also stated it more bluntly: PURPA requires its member utilities to buy power it often doesn’t even need at mandatory above-market prices. [S17] The National Rural Electric Cooperative Association and the American Public Power Association also supported FERC's proposed changes. [S18] A group of opponents, which included eight attorneys general, the FTC, and electric power supply companies, wrote FERC to express their opposition. [S19] They laid out their concerns that FERC would be overstepping its authority in making these changes, something legal and renewables groups had argued as well. [S20] The states also raised concerns that the rules could harm renewables deployment in their states and others according to the electric industry news site UTILITY DIVE.
